column2: lit. sunny mountain town) is a town and the administrative center of Solnechnogorsky District in Moscow Oblast
column4: located on the Moscow–St. Petersburg Highway and the Moscow–St. Petersburg railway
column5: on the coast of Senezh Lake
column6: 65 kilometers (40 mi) northwest from Moscow. Population: 52
column9: 554 (1989 Census).It was previously known as Solnechnaya Gora (until 1938).

column1: Originally a village named Solnechnaya Gora (Солнечная Гора)
column2: it was granted town status and renamed Solnechnogorsk in 1938. During World War II
column3: Solnechnogorsk was briefly occupied by the German Army from November 24 to December 12
column4: 1941. It was one of the towns that was captured in the northern pincer of the attempted German encirclement of Moscow.

column1: Within the framework of administrative divisions
column2: Solnechnogorsk serves as the administrative center of Solnechnogorsky District. As an administrative division
column5: incorporated within Solnechnogorsky District as the Town of Solnechnogorsk. As a municipal division
column6: the Town of Solnechnogorsk is incorporated within Solnechnogorsky Municipal District as Solnechnogorsk Urban Settlement.

column1: Industry in the town is represented by a metal construction factory

There is a museum of local lore in the town. Not far from Solnechnogorsk is the estate of Shakhmatovo that once belonged to a prominent Russian poet Alexander Blok; a museum of him has been opened there.

The town is the headquarters for the Main Centre for Missile Attack Warning. The Russian Ground Forces relocated the 18th Motor Rifle Brigade here from the Baltics from 1993 until the brigade was disbanded in 1998.
The town is the birthplace of the former Soviet hockey player Viktor Shalimov.
